sen.j: タギツヒメ（タキツヒメとも）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)で、宗像三女神の一柱である。
sen.e: Tagitsu-hime (also called Takitsu-hime) was the god (Shinto religion) appeared in Japanese Mythology and one of Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined in Munakata Taisha Shrine).
Tagitsu-hime (also called Takitsu-hime) was a god (Shinto religion) appearing in Japanese Mythology and one of Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined in Munakata Taisha Shrine).
Tagitsu-hime (also called Takitsu-hime) was a god (Shinto religion) appearing in Japanese Mythology and one of Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined in Munakata Taisha Shrine).

sen.j: 古事記では多岐都比売命、日本書紀では湍津姫と表記される。
sen.e: It was written as 多岐都比売命 in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and 湍津姫 in Nihonshoki (Chronicle of Japan).
sen.cmt: 漢字が焦点となっているため、漢字表記を訳文に残しました。
sen.e: It was written as 多岐都比売命 in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and 湍津姫 in Nihonshoki (Chronicle of Japan).
It was written as 多岐都比売命 in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and 湍津姫 in Nihonshoki (Chronicle of Japan).
Descriptions in the mythology
Descriptions in the mythology
Descriptions in the mythology

sen.j: アマテラスとスサノオの誓約の段で、アマテラスがスサノオの持つ剣を譲り受けて宗像三女神を生んだ。
sen.e: In the chapter of the pledge between Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Susano, Amaterasu got the sword Susano had and gave birth to Munakata Sanjojin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the chapter of the pledge between Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Susano, Amaterasu received the sword Susano had and gave birth to Munakata Sanjojin.
In the chapter of the pledge between Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Susano, Amaterasu received the sword Susano had and gave birth to Munakata Sanjojin.

sen.j: スサノオの物実から生まれたのでスサノオの子であると宣言された。
sen.e: She was born from Susano's monozane (medium to produce something), so she was declared as the child of Susano.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She was born from Susano's monozane (medium to produce something), so she was declared a child of Susano.
She was born from Susano's monozane (medium to produce something), so she was declared a child of Susano.

sen.j: この三女神は宗像の民が信仰している神であると記されている。
sen.e: It was described that people in Munakata believed in these three goddesses.
It was described that people in Munakata believed in these three goddesses.
It was described that people in Munakata believed in these three goddesses.

sen.j: 化生した順番や、どの宮に祀られるかは、記紀で異同がある。
sen.e: The order of metamorphosis and which shrine she was enshrined in varied in Kiki (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki).
The order of metamorphosis and which shrine she was enshrined in varied in Kiki (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki).
The order of metamorphosis and which shrine she was enshrined in varied in Kojiki and Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 古事記・日本書紀第二の一書では、3番目に化生し、辺津宮に祀られる。
sen.e: In the second alternate writing transmitted by Kojiki and Nihonshoki, she was metamorphosed third and enshrined in Hetsu-miya Shrine.
In the second alternate writing transmitted by Kojiki and Nihonshoki, she was the third to metamorphis and was enshrined in Hetsu-miya Shrine.
In the second alternate writing transmitted by Kojiki and Nihonshoki, she was the third to metamorphism and was enshrined in Hetsu-miya Shrine.

sen.j: 日本書紀本文・第一の一書・第三の一書では、2番目に化生し、中津宮に祀られる。
sen.e: In the main, the first, and the third alternate writings, she was metamorphosed second and enshrined in Nakatsu-no-miya Shrine.
In the main, the first, and the third alternate writings, she was second to metamorphis and was enshrined in Nakatsu-no-miya Shrine.
In the main, the first, and the third alternate writings in Nihonshoki, she was second to metamorphism and was enshrined in Nakatsu-no-miya Shrine.

sen.j: 宗像大社では、「湍津姫神」として中津宮に祀られている。
sen.e: In Munakata Taisha Shrine, she was enshrined as '湍津姫神' (Tagitsu-hime).
sen.cmt: 漢字が焦点となっているため、漢字表記を訳文に残しました。
sen.e: In Munakata Taisha Shrine, she was enshrined as '湍津姫神' (Tagitsu-hime).
In Munakata Taisha Shrine, she was enshrined as '湍津姫神' (Tagitsu-hime).

sen.j: 先代旧事本紀には、後に大国主に嫁ぎ、事代主と高照光姫命を生んだと記されている。
sen.e: In Sendai Kujihongi (Ancient Japanese History), it described that she married to Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) and gave birth to Kotoshiro nushi (a Japanese ancient god) and Takateruhime-no-mikoto.

In Sendai Kujihongi (Ancient Japanese History), it is described that she married Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) and gave birth to Kotoshiro nushi (a Japanese ancient god) and Takateruhime-no-mikoto.

In Sendai Kujihongi (Ancient Japanese History), it is described that she married Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) and gave birth to Kotoshiro nushi (a Japanese ancient god) and Takateruhime no mikoto.

sen.j: 神名の「タギツ」は「滾（たぎ）つ」（水が激しく流れる）の意で、天の安河の早瀬のことと解釈される。
sen.e: Her Shinmyo 'Tagitsu' meant '滾つ' (pronounced as tagitsu, meaning violently rolling water), and it is interpreted as the rapid of Ame no Yasukawa.
sen.cmt: 漢字が焦点となっているため、漢字表記を訳文に残しました。
sen.e: Her Shinmyo 'Tagitsu' meant '滾つ' (pronounced as tagitsu, meaning violently rolling water), and it is interpreted as being the rapids of Ame no Yasukawa.
Her Shinmyo 'Tagitsu' meant '滾つ' (pronounced as tagitsu, meaning violently rolling water), and it is interpreted as being the rapids of Ame no Yasukawa.

sen.j: タギツヒメを単独で祀る神社は少なく、宗像三女神の一柱として各地の宗像大社・厳島神社などで、また、アマテラスとスサノオの誓約で生まれた五男三女神とともに各地の八王子神社などで祀られている。
sen.e: There are only few shrines where only Tagitsu-hime is enshrined, but she is enshrined in Munakata Taisha Shrines and Itsukushima-jinja Shrines around the country as one of Munakata Sanjojin and she is also enshrined in Hachioji-jinja Shrines around the country with five gods and three goddesses born by the pledge between Amaterasu and Susano.

There are only a few shrines where Tagitsu-hime is enshrined, but she is enshrined in Munakata Taisha Shrines and Itsukushima-jinja Shrines around the country as one of Munakata Sanjojin and she is also enshrined in Hachioji-jinja Shrines around the country with five gods and three goddesses born by a pledge between Amaterasu and Susano.

There are only a few shrines where Tagitsu-hime is enshrined, but she is enshrined in Munakata Taisha Shrines and Itsukushima-jinja Shrines around the country as one of Munakata Sanjojin and she is also enshrined in Hachioji-jinja Shrines around the country with five gods and three goddesses born by a pledge between Amaterasu and Susano.
